Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election saw the Social Democratic Party (PSD) emerge as the largest political party in parliament, although they did not win an absolute majority (2,3). The election had a historically low turnout of 33.2% (10). The governing National Liberal Party (PNL) and the leftist Social Democrats (PSD) were neck and neck in the election, with the PSD ultimately securing 30% of the vote (8). However, the result of the election was ultimately too close to call (6,8).

Timeline.Text: The 2020 Romanian parliamentary election takes place, with the Social Democratic Party (PSD) and the National Liberal Party (PNL) emerging as the two largest political parties.
The PSD wins the election with 29.69% of the vote, beating the PNL's 25.18%.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election (10) saw the resignation of center-right Prime Minister Ludovic Orban (3, 6, 7, 8, 9). The election was held on 14 March 2021 (1) after a bill was submitted by Adrian Dohotaru and received support from the Social Democratic Party (PSD) (1). The new center-right majority, led by Prime Minister Florin Citu (2), faces a stormy year (2). President Klaus Iohannis was re-elected in 2019 (4) and appointed Nicolae-Ionel Ciuca as the interim prime minister (7). The voter turnout was historically low at 33.2% (10).

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian parliamentary election (1-10) took place on December 6, 2020 (1,4,6) and was preceded by an election campaign that started on November 6 and ended on December 5 (2). Exit polls showed different results, with Prime Minister Ludovic Orban claiming victory (3,8) and another poll showing the Social Democrat Party securing 30% of the vote (9). The election was also monitored by the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (7). The election was seen as pivotal for Romania's future in the European mainstream (3,9) and involved political parties such as the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats (1), the National Liberal Party (9), and the Union for Romania's Salvation (9). The election was also notable for the use of blockchain technology (4).

Timeline.Text: The election campaign for Romania's 2020 general elections officially begins.
The OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (ODIHR) deploys a special election assessment mission (SEAM) for the 6 December parliamentary elections in Romania.
Romanian Prime Minister Ludovic Orban claims victory in the national election, although one exit poll differs.
The Romanian parliamentary election takes place, with a record low voter turnout.
The Romanian government announces that blockchain technology was used in the election process.
The final results of the parliamentary election are announced, with the Social Democrat Party (PSD) winning the most seats.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election resulted in Ludovic Orban, the Prime Minister of Romania, resigning from his position (1). He distanced himself from Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban (2) and emphasized the importance of the election for the future of Romania (7). He also promised no post-election lockdown due to economic concerns (6). The election was held amid the COVID-19 pandemic and Orban is expected to be reelected (9). He also discussed the progress of the country's budget for 2021 (10).

Timeline.Text: Social-democrats demand that Ludovic Orban explain the government's budget plans for 2021 in Parliament.
Ludovic Orban distances himself from his Hungarian namesake Viktor Orban, defending the EU after Hungary and Poland's veto.
Ludovic Orban announces the completion of the first phase of the BRUA gas pipeline, a significant investment for Romania and Europe.
Ludovic Orban asserts that Hungary cannot speak for all EU member states.
Ludovic Orban guarantees that there will be no post-election lockdown in Romania.
Romania's center-right Prime Minister Ludovic Orban is set to be re-elected in the country's legislative elections.
Ludovic Orban votes in the parliamentary elections and states that it is a crucial day for Romania's future.
Ludovic Orban reacts to the early exit-poll results, claiming that even though PNL is currently placed second, they will still win the elections.
Ludovic Orban announces his resignation as Prime Minister following the parliamentary elections.

Overview.Summary: Nicolae Ciucă, the Romanian Defense Minister, has been named as the interim Prime Minister after Ludovic Orban resigned following his party's poor results in the 2020 Romanian legislative election (1, 8). Ciucă's connection to Sibiu was highlighted, as he received his education at the Academy of Foreign Trade (3). He also recently signed a ten-year roadmap with the United States Secretary of Defense (4). There has been speculation that Romania may enter a state of emergency due to the high number of COVID-19 cases (5). Ciucă has also been involved in discussions with representatives from the defense industry and the United States in regards to technology transfer and military cooperation (6). His appointment as interim Prime Minister was made by President Klaus Iohannis (7). The election is seen as a potential change in generation for Romania (9). Ciucă has a high military rank and was previously in the army before entering politics (10).

Nicolae Ciucă meets with representatives of the US defense industry during his visit to Washington.
Romania holds its parliamentary elections, with Ciucă expected to be a key player.

Overview.Summary: The 2020 Romanian legislative election took place on December 6, 2020 (1,2,5,8,15). It was initially scheduled for March 2021 but was moved forward to December 2020 (1,2). The Social Democratic Party (PSD) and the National Liberal Party (PNL) were the two main competitors (1,2,3,4,5,7,11,13,15,17,18). The PSD emerged as the largest party, followed by the PNL (11,13). Prime Minister Ludovic Orban resigned after his party's poor results (3,4). The election saw historically low turnout at 33.2% (17). There were also concerns about potential election interference (12,19,20).

Timeline.Text: The previous Romanian legislative election was held on this day, with the Social Democratic Party (PSD) and the National Liberal Party (PNL) emerging as the two main contenders.
Prime Minister Ludovic Orban resigns after his party, the PNL, fails to secure a majority in the parliamentary election.
The Social Democratic Party (PSD) secures 30% of the vote, followed by the PNL with 25% and the pro-EU Union for Romania's Salvation (USR-PLUS) with 15%.
The Romanian government announces that blockchain technology will be used in the 2020 legislative election.
Future date: the next Romanian legislative election is scheduled to take place on or before this day.
